A map is a relationship between two sets that associates every element in one set(domain) to exactly one element in another set (codomain).
For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the sum $\mathfrak{a}+\mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\{a+b ; a \in \mathfrak{a}, b \in \mathfrak{b}\}$.
Does the concept of a/an Map/Function need to be defined for a definition of a/an Sum of Ideals to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of a Sum of Ideals involves combining elements from two ideals, \\(\mathfrak{a}\\) and \\(\mathfrak{b}\\), within a ring \\(R\\) to form a new set. This new set, \\(\mathfrak{a}+\mathfrak{b}\\), consists of all possible sums of elements \\(a\\) from \\(\mathfrak{a}\\) and \\(b\\) from \\(\mathfrak{b}\\). The definition of Sum of Ideals does not inherently involve mapping elements from one set to another set in a way that each element of the first set is associated with exactly one element of the second set, as defined in the concept of a Map/Function.\n\nTherefore, the definition and understanding of a Sum of Ideals can be fully grasped without the need to define or use the concept of a Map/Function. The operations involved are internal to the set of the ring \\(R\\) and involve addition within the ring, not mapping between different sets.
